 I don't think it's propaganda; I think there are 2 reasons for this.
 
 1.) It reflects society at large. You have to remember that compared to typical relationships, gay ones are uncommon. You all make up somewhere less than 10% of the general population, and it's probably no more than 5% based on estimates I've read. When you're talking about a small percentage, it's naturally not going to be the default for things like prom stuff, history class, titles, etc. In fact, if you did have both a prom same-sex couple AND a prom opposite-sex couple it would be a poor representation of the school since it would imply more of a 50/50 ratio; but the vast majority would be more like the opposite-sex couple.
 
 2.) It reflects the fact that most people consider gays an unusual enigma, and let's face it, you are. There are a lot less of you, and you are attracted to one another in an unusual way, different from most people, that doesn't allow for intercourse and the normal human means of reproduction and procreation. Because it's so different, it's been a cause of ostricization. And yes, there should be more tolerance toward gays in terms of not thinking of them in a hateful way. But people tend to think that things far different from them are strange. That's just the way people are. I'm sure there are plenty of things you think are strange about people much different from you that you've seen too, if you stop to think about it.
 
 You're a part of a minority, so I'm sure it feels like everyone is against you. But the bottom line is that you are not like most everyone else in the world. When that's the case, you can't expect the whole world to change just to accomodate you. People in school face all kinds of feelings for being different. Society naturally defaults to portrayals of people that fit the norm for people in that society. For instance, what prince in the library book is a midget? Are you outraged about that too? How many schools have you seen that had sports teams specifically for the physically handicapped? For that matter, when have you seen kids in wheelchairs on sports teams with other kids?
 
 See what I'm saying here? The reason schools are the way you describe is because they tend to reflect society at large, and the things that are typical in that society.  THIS is how the "gay / natural/unnatural / good/bad" argument typically goes. I've seen this a thousand and one times. Virtually without fail, when you see argument #1 formed, the debater is eventually going to make fallacy #3.
 
 1) Anti-gay person: Gay is unnatural, and as such, it's bad.
 2) Pro-gay person: Gay is natural. It's found in numerous species in nature.
 3) Anti-gay person: So just because the animals do it makes it okay? That's dumb.
 
 You'll note that the pro-gay person refuted the NATURAL claim as the BASIS for the "bad" conclusion. The pro-gay person never actually said "natural is good".
 It is the ANTI-GAY person who brought the "natural:good / unnatural:bad" presumptions to the table. All the pro-gay person did was refute the FOUNDATION of the conclusion, and thus invalidating the conclusion.
 
 And of course, in step 3, the anti-gay person has totally missed (like Jyoshu) that the pro-gay person hasn't even commented on the "natural/good" assumption.
